user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calc_userdigest:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
calc_userdigest (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                 const char *username, const size_t username_len,
                 const char *realm, const size_t realm_len,
                 const char *password,
                 uint8_t *ha1_bin)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  digest_update (da, username, username_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update (da, realm, realm_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update_str (da, password);
  digest_calc_hash (da, ha1_bin);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the code uses standard C constructs (function definition syntax, parameter types like size_t and uint8_t from the C standard, struct pointer, const qualifiers, normal function calls and identifiers) and contains no explicit compiler-specific keywords or extension syntax such as __attribute__, __declspec, __asm, __builtin_*, __extension__, pragma with vendor tokens, inline assembler, or other documented compiler extensions. Identifiers and function names with leading underscores or underscores in names are not by themselves compiler extensions. Therefore only the two fragments above should be investigated further: _MHD_static_inline is a macro-like token that commonly expands to compiler-dependent inline/visibility/attribute qualifiers, and mhd_assert could expand to a compiler-specific assertion/diagnostic macro — both may hide compiler-specific extensions and should be checked in their definitions. No other code fragments in the shown function appear to use language/compiler extensions.
